Identification_Area.title: The Venetia Burney Student Dust Counter (SDC) for New Horizons

Modification_Detail.description: Updated schema version. Adding missing "investigation" references.
Changed inst LIDs from u:n:p:c:i:instID.scID to u:n:p:c:i:scID.instID And per "Guide toPDS4 Context Products" v1.7, changed all lidvid_reference to lid_reference

External_Reference.reference_text: Superseded by [HORANYIETAL2008], Horanyi, M., V. Hoxie, D. James, A. Poppe, C. Bryant, B. Grogan, B. Lamprecht, J. Mack, F. Bagenal, S. Batiste, N. Bunch, T. Chantanowich, F. Christensen, M. Colgan, T. Dunn, G. Drake, A. Fernandez, T. Finley, G. Holland, A. Jenkins, C. Krauss, E. Krauss, O. Krauss, M. Lankton, C. Mitchell, M. Neeland, T. Resse, K. Rash, G. Tate, C. Vaudrin, and J. Westfall, The Student Dust Counter on the New Horizons Mission, Space Sci. Rev., Volume 140, Numbers 1-4, pp. 387-402, 2008.

Superseded by [WEAVERETAL2008], Weaver, H.A., W.C. Gibson, M.B. Tapley, L.A. Young, and S.A. Stern, Overview of the New Horizons Science Payload, Space Sci. Rev., Volume 140, Numbers 1-4, pp. 75-91, 2008.

Instrument.name: The Venetia Burney Student Dust Counter (SDC) for New Horizons
Instrument.description: The Venetia Burney Student Dust Counter (SDC) is a student-designed experiment to characterize the dust particles of the outer solar system. The SDC can detect impacts with dust particles with masses in the range 4x10^-12 to 4X10^-9 grams. The instrument was renamed after launch to honor the 11-yr old girl who, in 1930, suggested the name “Pluto” for the newly discovered planetary body.
